content.question: A <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object moving at <math alttext="6 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> collides with a <math alttext="3 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object moving at <math alttext="4 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> in the same direction. Data for the momentum <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> for both objects is shown in the graph. Which of the following statements best describes this collision?

choices.label: The momentum of the two-object system is constant, and the magnitude of the relative velocity between the objects is the same before and after the collision.
The momentum of the two-object system is constant, and the magnitude of the relative velocity between the objects is different before and after the collision.

The momentum of the <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object is constant, and the magnitude of the relative velocity between the objects is the same before and after the collision.

The momentum of the <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object is not constant, and the magnitude of the relative velocity between the objects is different before and after the collision.

content.answer: The momentum of the two-object system is constant, and the magnitude of the relative velocity between the objects is the same before and after the collision.
